expectedResults.title: Path Traversal Vulnerability
expectedResults.reason: Expected vulnerability allowing access to files outside intended directory through inadequate input validation was not detected in the actual penetration test findings. The test focused on server configuration and application-level security issues but did not discover path traversal vulnerabilities in the index.html file or related endpoints.

expectedResults.title: Local File Inclusion (LFI)
expectedResults.reason: Expected vulnerability allowing inclusion and reading of local system files through inadequate input validation was not detected. While the penetration test discovered various security issues, none of them relate to local file inclusion attacks or file manipulation parameters that could be exploited to include unintended files.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application is missing critical security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, HSTS, Referrer-Policy) that protect against multiple attack vectors including clickjacking, MIME sniffing, and XSS attacks.

actualResults.title: HTTP TRACE Method Enabled - Cross-Site Tracing (XST)
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Apache TRACE method is enabled, allowing potential XST attacks that could bypass HTTPOnly cookie restrictions and expose sensitive headers including Authorization tokens and session cookies.

actualResults.title: Apache Version Information Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Server header reveals Apache version (2.4.50) and platform information, enabling targeted exploitation and reconnaissance by attackers.

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Contact Form
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Contact form lacks CSRF token protection and other anti-CSRF mechanisms, allowing attackers to perform unauthorized form submissions on behalf of users through crafted malicious webpages.

actualResults.title: .htaccess File Exists and Returns 403 Forbidden
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Apache configuration file existence can be discovered through HTTP status code differentiation (403 vs 404), revealing application configuration structure to attackers.

actualResults.title: Outdated JavaScript Libraries with Known Vulnerabilities
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Application loads outdated versions of jQuery (3.5.1), Popper.js (2.9.2), and Bootstrap (4.5.2) containing known CVEs and security vulnerabilities including XSS and prototype pollution issues.

actualResults.title: Client-Side Validation Bypass - Empty Fields Accepted
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Contact form relies exclusively on client-side validation; server accepts POST requests with empty required fields, invalid email formats, XSS payloads, and oversized inputs without any server-side validation.

actualResults.title: HTTP POST Method Allowed on Static Files
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Apache accepts HTTP POST requests on static HTML files, violating HTTP method semantics and potentially enabling CSRF attacks or confusing security controls.

actualResults.title: Missing Subresource Integrity (SRI) for CDN-loaded Resources
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. JavaScript and CSS libraries loaded from CDNs lack SRI integrity attributes, allowing potential supply chain attacks where compromised CDNs or MITM attackers could serve malicious library versions.

actualResults.title: No Rate Limiting on Contact Form - DoS/Spam Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Contact form endpoint has no rate limiting or throttling mechanisms, allowing attackers to perform unlimited rapid submissions for DoS attacks, spam generation, and resource exhaustion.

missed.title: Path Traversal Vulnerability
missed.reason: Expected vulnerability allowing access to files outside intended directory through inadequate input validation was not detected in the actual penetration test findings. The test focused on server configuration and application-level security issues but did not discover path traversal vulnerabilities in the index.html file or related endpoints.

missed.title: Local File Inclusion (LFI)
missed.reason: Expected vulnerability allowing inclusion and reading of local system files through inadequate input validation was not detected. While the penetration test discovered various security issues, none of them relate to local file inclusion attacks or file manipulation parameters that could be exploited to include unintended files.
